noun.description: A dry measure used for grain, meat, salt, etc.
A liquid measure of widely varying capacity; a cask holding this amount.

origin: Late Middle English; earliest use found in Geoffrey Chaucer (c1340–1400), poet and administrator. From Anglo-Norman and Middle French mui measure of capacity, Middle French, French muid from classical Latin modius<br>late 18th century. From South African Dutch muid from French muid.
